perturbation.original_text: 7.1 TERM. The term of this Agreement shall be five years commencing on the Effective Date and ending at the close of business on the fifth anniversary of the Effective Date. This Agreement shall automatically renew for successive one-year terms unless one party gives the other party written notice of non-renewal at least six months prior to automatic renewal.
perturbation.changed_text: 7.1 TERM. The term of this Agreement shall be five years commencing on the Effective Date and ending at the close of business on the fifth anniversary of the Effective Date. This Agreement shall automatically renew for successive one-year terms unless one party gives the other party written notice of non-renewal at least one month prior to automatic renewal.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires a six-month notice for non-renewal. Reducing this to one month may not provide sufficient time, especially in complex business relationships, potentially conflicting with general contract law principles requiring reasonable notice.

perturbation.original_text:
7.2 TERMINATION. Either party may terminate this Agreement without penalty and without prejudice to any claims arising prior to termination as follows:

               (a) Upon the written agreement of both parties.

               (b) Upon the other party's breach of this Agreement provided          the terminating party has given written notice of the breach to the          other party specifying the breach, the action necessary to cure the          breach and the breaching party has not cured the breach within five          business days after notice is given of any failure by NPC to provide          any funds required hereunder to be provided by NPC to pay Merchants or          within thirty business days after notice is given of any other breach.
perturbation.changed_text:
7.2 TERMINATION. Either party may terminate this Agreement without penalty and without prejudice to any claims arising prior to termination as follows:

               (a) Upon the written agreement of both parties.

               (b) Upon the other party's breach of this Agreement provided          the terminating party has given written notice of the breach to the          other party specifying the breach, the action necessary to cure the          breach and the breaching party has not cured the breach within two          business days after notice is given of any failure by NPC to provide          any funds required hereunder to be provided by NPC to pay Merchants or          within fifteen business days after notice is given of any other breach.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a breach of contract, particularly regarding payment failures, from five to two business days may be considered unreasonably short, potentially violating principles of fair dealing and adequate opportunity to remedy a default. Similarly, reducing the cure period for any other breach from thirty to fifteen business days may also be seen as unreasonable depending on the nature and complexity of the breach.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Opportunity to Cure Breach

perturbation.original_text: Notices sent by United States Mail, certified mail, return receipt requested, are given five business days after delivery to the United States Postal Service unless prior actual receipt by the addressee is proven.
perturbation.changed_text: Notices sent by United States Mail, certified mail, return receipt requested, are given ten business days after delivery to the United States Postal Service unless prior actual receipt by the addressee is proven.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the notice period to ten business days after mailing through certified mail contradicts the established legal expectation of prompt notice, especially in legally binding contracts. This delay could cause material harm to one or both parties and could lead to the recipient arguing they did not receive proper notice.
